debunk.example: Richard Dawkins tries to debunk religious belief, but his ridicule tends to push people away from his points rather than convince them.

obscure.example: Many of the biggest movie stars were once obscure actors who got only bit roles in long forgotten films.

mendacity.example: I can forgive her for her mendacity but only because she is a child and is seeing what she can get away with.

anodyne.example: Wilbur enjoyed a spicy Mexican breakfast, but Jill prefered a far more anodyne meal in the mornings.

discriminate.example: Sarah couldn't discriminate between a good wine and a bad wine, so she avoided wine tastings.

cede.example: Eventually, all parents must cede control of their growing childrens' educations and allow their offspring some autonomy.

ravenous.example: John didn't each much at all during the week he had the flu, so now that he is regaining his health, it's not surpring that he has a ravenous appetite.
ravenous.definition: extremely hungry; devouring or craving food in great quantities

garrulous.example: Lynne was garrulous: once, she had a fifteen minute conversation with a stranger before she realized the woman didn't speak English.

aplomb.example: Nancy acted with aplomb during dangerous situations--she once calmly climbed up an oak tree to save a cat.
aplomb.definition: great coolness and composure under strain

derivative.example: work of another person Because the movies were utterly derivative of other popular movies, they did well at the box office.
derivative.definition: (or a creative product, e.g. music, writing, etc.) not original but drawing on the

upbraid.example: Bob took a risk walking into the "Students Barbershop"--in the end he had to upbraid the apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.

hobble.example: Bad weather has hobbled rescue efforts, making it difficult for crews to find bodies in the wreckage.
hobble.definition: to hold back  the progress of something

nettlesome.example: Maria found her coworkers cell phone nettlesome, because every few minutes it would buzz to life with another text message.

parvenu.example: higher class The theater was full of parvenus who each thought that they were surrounded by true aristocrats.
parvenu.definition: a person who has suddenly become wealthy, but not socially accepted as part of a

respite.example: Every afternoon, the small company has a respite in which workers play foosball or board games.
respite.definition: a pause from doing something (as work)

foible.example: When their new roommate sat staring at an oak tree for an hour, Marcia thought it indicated a mental problem, but Jeff assured her it was a harmless foible.
foible.definition: a behavioral attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual

fickle.example: She was so fickle in her politics, it was hard to pinpoint her beliefs; one week she would embrace a side, and the next week she would denounce it.
fickle.definition: liable to sudden unpredictable change, esp. in affections or attachments

unseemly.example: He acted in an unseemly manner, insulting the hostess and then speaking ill of her deceased husband.
unseemly.definition: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite society

carping.example: What seemed like incessant nagging and carping about my behavior from my mother turned out to be wise and useful advice that has served me well.

tact.example: In a tremendous display of tact, Shelly was able to maintain a strong friendship with Marcia, even though Marcia's husband, Frank, confessed to finding Shelley more attractive than Marcia.
tact.definition: consideration in dealing with others and avoiding giving offense

fete.example: After World War II, war heroes were feted at first but quickly forgotten.

picayune.example: English teachers are notorious for being picayune; however, the English language is so nuanced and sophisticated that often such teachers are not being contrary but are only adhering to the rules.

belie.example: The smile on her face belies the pain she must feel after the death of her husband.
belie.definition: to give a false representation to; misrepresent

abjure.example: While the church believed that Galileo abjured the heliocentric theory under threat of torture, he later wrote a book clearly supporting the theory.
abjure.definition: formally reject or give up (as a belief)

augment.example: Ideally, the restaurant's augmented menu will expand its clientele and increase its profits.

mitigate.example: If it weren't for the mitigating circumstances, he would have certainly lost his job.

elegiac.example: Few can listen to the elegiac opening bars of the Moonlight sonata without feeling the urge to cry.

appurtenant.example: In hiking Mt. Everest, sherpas are appurtenant, helping climbers both carry gear and navigate treacherous paths.

apogee.example: The apogee of the Viennese style of music, Mozart's music continues to mesmerize audiences well into the 21st century.

prolific.example: Schubert was the most prolific composer, producing hundreds of hours of music before he died at the age of 31.

acerbic.example: Most movie critics are acerbic towards summer blockbusters, often referring to them as garbage.

imbibe.example: Plato imbibed Socrates' teachings to such an extent that he was able to write volumes of work that he directly attributed, sometimes word for word, to Socrates.
imbibe.definition: to drink or absorb as if drinking

reprisal.example: The Old Testament doctrine of an eye for an eye is not the kind of retaliation practiced in war; rather, an arm, a leg, and both ears are the reprisal for the smallest scratch.
reprisal.definition: a retaliatory action against an enemy in wartime

innocuous.example: Everyone found Nancy's banter innocuous--except for Mike, who felt like she was intentionally picking on him.
innocuous.definition: harmless and doesn"t produce any ill effects

tempered.example: The wide-eyed optimism of her youth was now tempered after she had worked many years in the criminal justice system.

subterfuge.example: Finally deciding to abandon all subterfuge, Arthur revealed to Cindy everything about his secret affair over the past two years.
subterfuge.definition: something intended to misrepresent the true nature of an activity

rash.example: Although Bruce was able to make the delivery in time with a nightime motorcycle ride in the rain, Susan criticized his actions as rash.
rash.definition: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences; imprudently incurring risk

enumerate.example: I sat and listened as she enumerated all of the things she did not like about the past three months.

gaffe.example: In a famous gaffe, Vice President Quayle attempted to correct the spelling of a grade school student, only to find that the child was correct.
gaffe.definition: a socially awkward or tactless act

jingoism.example: North Korea maintains intense control over its population through a combination of jingoism and cult of personality.

itinerant.example: Doctors used to be itinerant, traveling between patients' homes.
itinerant.definition: traveling from place to place to work

furtive.example: While at work, George and his boss Regina felt the need to be as furtive as possible about their romantic relationship.
furtive.definition: marked by quiet and caution and secrecy; taking pains to avoid being observed

capricious.example: Nearly every month our capricious CEO had a new plan to turn the company around, and none of them worked because we never gave them the time they needed to succeed.
capricious.definition: determined by chance or impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason

exacerbate.example: Her sleeplessness exacerbated her cold--when she woke up the next day, her sinuses were completely blocked.
